item.title: Comment on Introducing the Abject Kitten, Part 1 by Xiao Yingtai
item.dc:creator: Xiao Yingtai
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/introducing-the-abject-kitten-part-1/#comment-1062">Jess Mahler</a>.
It's funny how our identity crises were about totally different identities, and yet I hear this huge reverberating gong of recognition inside me when you describe yours. I'm so glad you figured it out.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Jess Mahler.

It’s funny how our identity crises were about totally different identities, and yet I hear this huge reverberating gong of recognition inside me when you describe yours. I’m so glad you figured it out.

item.title: Comment on My Emotional Masochism Isn’t Therapy by Xiao Yingtai
item.dc:creator: Xiao Yingtai
item.description: I hope 2 months later isn't too late to have a conversation, because I'm now replying to your comment 3 months late! If I understand you correctly, we don't disagree. I said my emotional masochism isn't about therapy, and you listed several motivations behind things that look like masochism.
item.content:encoded: I hope 2 months later isn’t too late to have a conversation, because I’m now replying to your comment 3 months late! If I understand you correctly, we don’t disagree. I said my emotional masochism isn’t about therapy, and you listed several motivations behind things that look like masochism.

item.title: Comment on Communicating While Submissive by Naga di Kandang
item.dc:creator: Naga di Kandang
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/communicating-while-submissive-in-full/#comment-1066">Xiao Yingtai</a>.
Yingtai, I'm the same way. The authority/power relationship is <i>always</i> in place, and that's how we want and need it. That does not exclude communication about uncomfortable topics or even complaints, but always still respectful and even deferential
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Xiao Yingtai.

Yingtai, I’m the same way. The authority/power relationship is always in place, and that’s how we want and need it. That does not exclude communication about uncomfortable topics or even complaints, but always still respectful and even deferential

item.title: Comment on Let’s Talk About Masochism by Xiao Yingtai
item.dc:creator: Xiao Yingtai
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/self-esteem-for-bottoms/#comment-1051">cdibbs</a>.
Survival is good. But I hope your path brings you all the way to fulfillment in the end. If it doesn't, there are always other paths. It's never too late!
item.content:encoded:
In reply to cdibbs.

Survival is good. But I hope your path brings you all the way to fulfillment in the end. If it doesn’t, there are always other paths. It’s never too late!

item.title: Comment on Communicating While Submissive by Xiao Yingtai
item.dc:creator: Xiao Yingtai
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/communicating-while-submissive-in-full/#comment-1049">Tilari</a>.
Thank you for reminding readers of this possibility. Setting aside time to check in with each other in a power-neutral way is often recommended, so I'm guessing it works really well for a lot of people. I must be the odd one out. :) If I feel like Person X has authority over me, then it is always hard to tell them things they might not like to hear, but I literally don't know how to do it in a power-neutral way. I can prostrate myself or brat, but polite vanilla doesn't seem to be an option that's available to me in those relationships. But definitely everyone should do whatever works best for them!
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Tilari.

Thank you for reminding readers of this possibility. Setting aside time to check in with each other in a power-neutral way is often recommended, so I’m guessing it works really well for a lot of people. I must be the odd one out. :) If I feel like Person X has authority over me, then it is always hard to tell them things they might not like to hear, but I literally don’t know how to do it in a power-neutral way. I can prostrate myself or brat, but polite vanilla doesn’t seem to be an option that’s available to me in those relationships. But definitely everyone should do whatever works best for them!

item.title: Comment on Introducing the Abject Kitten, Part 1 by Jess Mahler
item.dc:creator: Jess Mahler
item.description: Somewhat the other way around for me. Several things had me convinced I was supposed to be a sub--I like being tied up and I'm a masochist. And it was fun, until it wasn't, but it never worked. I slowly, with the support of a friend, started exploring domination. I ID'd as a switch for a while, but it was like a wool shirt--irritated even when it fit right. Took me a long time to realize that being a rope slut and a masochist did not make me submissive, that I could be a dominant who just happens to like pain and bondage.
item.content:encoded: Somewhat the other way around for me. Several things had me convinced I was supposed to be a sub–I like being tied up and I’m a masochist. And it was fun, until it wasn’t, but it never worked. I slowly, with the support of a friend, started exploring domination. I ID’d as a switch for a while, but it was like a wool shirt–irritated even when it fit right. Took me a long time to realize that being a rope slut and a masochist did not make me submissive, that I could be a dominant who just happens to like pain and bondage.

item.title: Comment on My Emotional Masochism Isn’t Therapy by Melissa
item.dc:creator: Melissa
item.description:
Hope it's not too late to have a conversation about this. 2 months later isn't too late is it?
This article is why I don't consider myself a masochist.
There are many reasons to want someone to hurt you and I have come up with several reasons to want to be hurt. Therapy is one motivation that could lead someone wanting pain even if they don't get pleasure from pain. Or someone could get an ego boost for being able to endure something even if they don't enjoy it in and of itself.
I personally love to feel things intensely so something that I hate might be a desirable experience just because it's intense. Therefore I might enjoy a painful experience not because I like pain but because I like intensity. I might enjoy a painful experience because it's surreal. Or because it's unfamiliar.
Another thing is that everyone enjoys mild pain. That's what I think anyway. People like spicy food because it's painful (and therefore stimulating) but at the same time most people (myself included) will enjoy any unpleasant stimulation (due to the fact that it's still a stimulation) up until the point where it's overwhelming. I think that's different from masochism but it can motivate people who aren't masochistic to seek out something painful.
item.content:encoded:
Hope it’s not too late to have a conversation about this. 2 months later isn’t too late is it?

This article is why I don’t consider myself a masochist.

There are many reasons to want someone to hurt you and I have come up with several reasons to want to be hurt. Therapy is one motivation that could lead someone wanting pain even if they don’t get pleasure from pain. Or someone could get an ego boost for being able to endure something even if they don’t enjoy it in and of itself.

I personally love to feel things intensely so something that I hate might be a desirable experience just because it’s intense. Therefore I might enjoy a painful experience not because I like pain but because I like intensity. I might enjoy a painful experience because it’s surreal. Or because it’s unfamiliar.

Another thing is that everyone enjoys mild pain. That’s what I think anyway. People like spicy food because it’s painful (and therefore stimulating) but at the same time most people (myself included) will enjoy any unpleasant stimulation (due to the fact that it’s still a stimulation) up until the point where it’s overwhelming. I think that’s different from masochism but it can motivate people who aren’t masochistic to seek out something painful.

item.title: Comment on Let’s Talk About Masochism by cdibbs
item.dc:creator: cdibbs
item.description: This is a lot to think about, all good stuff. I am not religious, but spiritual. I am submissive to those I cannot control or have no power over. I observe them, try to encompass myself in their power. I feel I hold onto my own power if I accept this or them as just that, and allow whatever to happen...Not sure if this is self destructive, or just my way of humbling and surviving.
item.content:encoded: This is a lot to think about, all good stuff. I am not religious, but spiritual. I am submissive to those I cannot control or have no power over. I observe them, try to encompass myself in their power. I feel I hold onto my own power if I accept this or them as just that, and allow whatever to happen…Not sure if this is self destructive, or just my way of humbling and surviving.

item.title: Comment on Communicating While Submissive by Tilari
item.dc:creator: Tilari
item.description:
One method that my Captain and I use for communication is setting aside time for a service/relationship/etc check-in. This time can be requested by either myself or my Captain, and the first free time we have goes to it. One difference our check-in has from some of the methods you've described is that we intentionally create a power-neutral space so we're communicating on an equal level, which, come to think of it, may make this completely off-topic from the point of your post. :P
But I figured I'd chip in my two cents on another communication option in a power exchange relationship. :)
item.content:encoded:
One method that my Captain and I use for communication is setting aside time for a service/relationship/etc check-in. This time can be requested by either myself or my Captain, and the first free time we have goes to it. One difference our check-in has from some of the methods you’ve described is that we intentionally create a power-neutral space so we’re communicating on an equal level, which, come to think of it, may make this completely off-topic from the point of your post. :P

But I figured I’d chip in my two cents on another communication option in a power exchange relationship. :)

item.title: Comment on My Emotional Masochism Isn’t Therapy by Xiao Yingtai
item.dc:creator: Xiao Yingtai
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/emotional-masochism-is-not-therapy/#comment-1013">sciophilous</a>.
If both of you don't feel right about it, then I got something wrong. I think I failed to edit out my initial disbelief that anyone could experience kink as therapy. By the time I finished writing I definitely realised that people are just different, and I tried to say so somewhere, but evidently the piece still has a sceptical tone. Apologies! I think it's fantastic that you guys can do this.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to sciophilous.

If both of you don’t feel right about it, then I got something wrong. I think I failed to edit out my initial disbelief that anyone could experience kink as therapy. By the time I finished writing I definitely realised that people are just different, and I tried to say so somewhere, but evidently the piece still has a sceptical tone. Apologies! I think it’s fantastic that you guys can do this.
